channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Remote and ready to run. Remote Perl role in UK
item.description: Day to day, you’ll manage the life cycle of software projects. That may mean consultation, design, development, testing, and deployment, and will include a mix of new projects, refactoring of legacy code, and stomping bugs. If you enjoy writing your own tools using Perl, Bash, HTML, CSS, and JS, this is the role for you.

item.title: Cruise into this Dreamy Career. Perl role in Malta
item.description: Our client is an international company who pride themselves on making online trading a breeze. After twenty-plus years cruising the financial waters, they're subject matter experts who provide a stable, engaging environment for their crew. Looking for Perl developers with a strong background in Modern Perl – you should be comfortable with Moose and PSGI/Plack.

item.title: Is your Python as good as your Perl? Perl/Python role in London
item.description: Our client is at the pinnacle of the premium native advertising game for corporate, tech, financial services, and lifestyle technology. This role is for a Senior Developer who is equally comfortable with Perl AND Python. You'll use server-side code, client-side code, databases, and websites to develop their software platform.

item.title: Senior Perl Developer with Cross-Trained Chops. UK Remote Perl Role
item.description: The best senior developers know that variety is the spice of life. Sure, you’ve got Perl chops for days, but that’s not all you can do — and that's why our client wants to meet you. They're looking for senior Perl developers, Node engineers, and those with mighty Python and SQL skills to lead their team.

item.title: Let’s get SaaSsy! Remote Perl role within US time zone
item.description: Our client is the world's leading provider of award-winning intelligent SaaS solutions for clients ranging from first responders and engineers to manufacturers and educators. The successful candidate is a Perl developer with Catalyst and DBlx::Class. You've been around the block and you know your stuff.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Pisano's Fortune
item.description: For me, the highlight of Roger's blog is that we get the glimpse of solutions in a guest language. Thank you for all the support and encouragements.

item.title: Bigint week
item.description: Breakdown of a task into smaller subtasks, makes it so easy to follow. Thank you for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 155
item.description: Luis' one-liner is the main attraction every week. Thank you for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 155: Fortunate and Pisano in Primes
item.description: Personally for me, I enjoyed the PostgreSQL solution more than anything else. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 155: Fortunate Numbers and Pisano Periods
item.description: Thank you for sharing the cool regex for Pisano Period. Thanks for sharing the knowledge with us every week!

item.title: PWC155 - Pisano Period
item.description: The detailed analysis of the task makes it easy to follow the code. Keep it up, great work.

item.title: PWC155 - Fortunate Numbers
item.description: Flavio's blog seems to be more Raku-centric than Perl, and I am not complaining. In fact, I enjoy it thoroughly.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge #155
item.description: James is known for his compact solutions. This week, we got pisano_period(), showing his Perl power. Keep it up, great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 155
item.description: Raku subroutine can be named as symbol, a really cool feature. Thank you for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: I Ain't No Fortunate One
item.description: The use of regex is fun, and the discussion around it is fun to read. Thank you for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: Pisa Party
item.description: I enjoyed the discussion about the difficulties in Pisano Period. Highly recommended.

item.title: The Fortunate Son
item.description: I liked the one-liner in Raku. Task analysis is the main attraction for me in the blog. Keep it up great work.

item.title: TWC 155: I say Potato, you say Pisano
item.description: Bonus in this week's blog is the solutions in Julia for the first time by Bruce. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Pisano the Fortunate
item.description: The unique style of blogging with links to the official documentation makes the blog much more fun. Thank you for everything.

item.title: Fortunate Pisano
item.description: The best part of Adam's blog is the Notes section where everything is explained. Thank you.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 151
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 155
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Fortunate Numbers" and "Pisano Period" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 156
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks - "Pernicious Numbers" and "Weird Number". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Dancer2: Hello World with Visual Studio Code
Cloud Provider Performance Comparison - Perl and more
Release 1.30 of Date::Holidays - more holiday for the French
#555 - Holidays
item.description:
Hi there!

I am in Hungary now where where there is a 4-days Holiday around the 15th March - the Hungarian version of the Springtime of Nations revolutions.

Then I'll have another 2 days off as my client in Israel celebrates Purim.

I use these free days to work on an open source platform for word-games. It is not ready yet to show the world, but it is already in a condition where people can contribute to it. The first game needs lots of words in various languages. I already started to do versions in English, Hungarian, Hebrew, and Ladino and I already had a contributor with French and German, but I am looking for more people who might be interested in contributing in other languages. Let me know and I can show you the game. I hope that two weeks from now, when I am editing the next issue of the Perl Weekly I'll be able to link to the game. (the game is only front-end code now so there is no Perl in it. Sorry.)

Enjoy your week!
item.dc:subject: list of tags?
